S3.T4.fig1.1.table:
3D Conv Dice
conv (k=3) 75.1
MS conv (k=3) 78.9
conv (k=5) 75.9
MS conv (k=5) 79.0
S3.T4.fig1.1.caption: Table 2:  Ablation on 3D conv adapters
references:
Effectiveness of the multi-scale 3D convolution module.
To validate the effectiveness of this module, we conducted four sets of experiments. Firstly, we replaced the multi-scale (MS) 3D convolution layers with kernel size r4×r×3×1×1𝑟4𝑟311\frac{r}{4}\times r\times 3\times 1\times 1divide start_ARG italic_r end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG × italic_r × 3 × 1 × 1 shown in Fig. 2(c) with a single 3D convolution layer with kernel size r×r×3×1×1𝑟𝑟311r\times r\times 3\times 1\times 1italic_r × italic_r × 3 × 1 × 1. Secondly, we increased the kernel size along the depth dimension from 3333 to 5555. Table. 4 shows that the MS design significantly enhances performance, benefiting from the expansion of the model’s local receptive field.

Effectiveness of the scanning strategy.
Table. 4 shows that scanning from depth-width planes surpasses both volume flattening and scanning from height-width planes, primarily due to its more effective capture of depth-level and 3D structural information. Furthermore, ensemble scanning across all three planes (height-width, depth-width, and depth-height) further boosts performance

Effectiveness of the low rank r𝑟ritalic_r. As shown in Table. 4, our algorithm maintains a consistent performance across different values of r𝑟ritalic_r, presenting strong robustness without significant fluctuations in performance.
